Ontarians trying to process Hank calling the Lake Superior area "southern Ontario": does not compute.

That's deep in northern Ontario (even if it is on the southern shores of the province). Southern Ontario is the heavily populated southern peninsular area south west of around Lake Simcoe and maybe midway along the coast of Lake Ontario (roughly the bedroom communities of Toronto out to Detroit and Buffalo). Eastern Ontario is east of there but south of the Sudbury/North Bay area (basically broad regions around Ottawa and Kingston). Southern Ontario has the bulk of the province's population (and strong ties to the Midwest) and Eastern Ontario has most of the remainder (and closer ties Quebec and upstate New York).

In theory, the area out around Lake Superior should be Western Ontario but in practice, everything from Sudbury and North Bay north and all the way west to the Manitoba border is the sparsely populated region referred to as Northern Ontario. Aside from a few modest sized cities on the edges, Northern Ontario is like a gigantic, emptier version of the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.

I have several thoughts and curiosities:

1) I want to better understand the relationship between climate cycles and tectonic activity. When do periods of glaciation align with increased or decreased tectonic movement, if at all? And does a colder Earth slow tectonic activity at all? Do we see greater tectonic, volcanic, geologic, etc. activity during certain times corresponding to climate cycles? Plainly, do plates move more or less or the same during times of glaciation or snowball Earth situations?

2) Would a supercontinent cycle, or the Wilson cycle, potentially point to a major impact event in Earth's past? I wonder: Why is it the lighter continental crust groups up? Wouldn't it be the case that a cooling Earth early on would have a more even distribution of oceanic and continental crusts? OR

3) Is the time scale for geologic activity so long that maybe Earth is still working out the kinks, so to speak? Are we still in the midst of the formation of Earth? More philosophically, is the Earth ever done forming? What do we mean when we say that?

I have more. I think I've already been pretty long-winded. 😆
